{{primary sources|date=April 2009}} {{Infobox political party | name = Jewish Socialists' Group | country = United Kingdom | affiliation = [[International Jewish Labor Bund]] | foundation = 1970s | website = http://www.jewishsocialist.org.uk/ |}} {{Jewish Labour Bund}} The '''Jewish Socialists' Group (JSG)''' is a [[Jewish]] [[socialist]] [[collective]] in [[United Kingdom|Britain]], formed in the 1970s.
==History==
The '''Jewish Socialists' Group (JSG)''' is a [[Jewish]] [[socialist]] [[collective]] in [[United Kingdom|Britain]], that was founded in [[Manchester]]/[[Liverpool]] in 1974-1977 as lobby group campaigning against the [[fascist]] [[British National Front|National Front]] and for the [[left-wing politics|left]] to relate more positively to Jewish issues. A [[London]] branch formed in 1977.<ref name=history>[http://www.jewishsocialist.org.uk/history1.html Jewish Socialists' Group timeline]</ref> They describe themselves as "a political organisation campaigning for [[Jewish rights]] and the rights of all [[oppressed minorities]] in building a [[socialist]] future."<ref name=about>[http://www.jewishsocialist.org.uk/whoweare.html About Jewish Socialists]</ref>
The JSG supported the original [[Anti-Nazi League]] and was active in street-level [[militant anti-fascism]]. It participated in the [[Beyond the Fragments]] conference which sought to renew [[democratic socialism]].
In the early 1980s, it was active in campaigning for peace in [[Israel]]/[[Palestine]], becoming a founding member of the [[International Jewish Peace Union]] and the [[Campaign for Israel-Palestine Peace]] (CIPP).
It developed a perspective drawing on the tradition of the [[General Jewish Labour Bund in Lithuania, Poland and Russia|Bund]], stressing [[Secular Jewish culture|Yiddishism]], [[cultural pluralism]] and a commitment to the vitality of the [[Jewish diaspora|diaspora]]. In this it worked with French neo-Bundist [[Richard Marienstrasse]] and the [[Medem Jewish Socialist Group]] in [[New York City|New York]].
In the mid-1980s, it became associated with the [[Greater London Council]]'s [[municipal socialism]] and [[multiculturalism]], receiving funding to launch [[Jewish Cultural and Anti-Racist Project]] (JCARP). It was frequently in conflict with the Jewish communal leadership, and in particular the [[Association of Jewish Ex-Servicemen]] (AJEX).
==Publications==
A magazine, ''Jewish Socialist'', was launched in 1985, which continues publication today.<ref name=magazine>[http://www.jewishsocialist.org.uk/jewishsocialist.html Jewish Socialists Magazine]</ref> Some of the figures associated with the JSG in this period included [[Battle of Cable Street]] veteran [[Charlie Goodman]], [[Joe Garman]], veteran Jewish [[trade union]]ist [[Mick Mindel]], poet [[Michael Rosen]], and Bundist veteran [[Majer Bogdanski]].
